p: VHF prevention hinges on reducing contact between humans and wildlife. A key epidemiological research strategy involves tracing the chain of clinical cases to an “index transmission event,” the moment when the virus spills over from its natural reservoir to the human host. Robust qualitative—to say nothing of ethnographic—evidence is rarely marshalled into those forensic accounts. However, human–animal relationships have long occupied a central place in anthropological inquiry (e.g., Douglas 1970; Evans-Pritchard 1940; Geertz 1994; Lévi-Strauss 1963; Rappaport 1968) and, with the emergence of multi-species ethnography as a mode of nature–culture critique, the discipline can clearly contribute much more towards illuminating the processes and pressures of coexistence (e.g., Haraway 2008; Kelly and Lezaun 2014; Kirksey and Helmreich 2010; Raffles 2010).
